title: Mum with epilepsy can't cuddle her baby because she could fit and black out
text:

A new mum with epilepsy has told how she can't carry or cuddle her baby all the time because she could suffer a fit, collapse and black out.

Beth Sodden, from Glasgow, is frightened of the risk to her eight-month-old daughter Jessica after she had a seizure while holding her.

The 30-year-old first-time mum is now fighting for access to medical cannabis oil, hoping it could be used to reduce her seizures.

Beth, who was diagnosed with epilepsy at 14, suffers a number of fits every week that can cause her to collapse, injure herself and black out, she told the Daily Record.

Doctors have been unable to determine the exact type of epilepsy she has.

(Image: Daily Record)

Beth said she and her partner James Hanlon, 36, are worried she could suffer another fit while holding Jessica.

She said: “Once I had just finished feeding Jessica and began burping her. James had nipped out of the room and heard Jessica crying.

“He says when he heard her still crying after a minute, he came back to find me having a seizure still holding Jessica.

“James quickly took her from me and put her in her basket before lying me down to make sure I didn’t injure myself.”

James added: “Beth was having a seizure and because she had been burping Jessica she still had her hand around her neck.

(Image: Daily Record)

“After that we knew we needed to find ­something to help control this.

“Cannabis oil is available and it is used in the UK but it isn’t readily available for people like Beth and it needs to be.”

“I’ve read accounts of people breaking the law to get their hands on it and if I have no other choice, I’ll do the same because I want to keep my partner and baby safe.”

Beth said: “James works 40 hours a week and I am here alone with Jessica. I’m always on edge because I could have a seizure at any point.

"I can’t bath Jessica alone and I’ve to limit the amount of times I lift or carry her, which is so hard when she cries and you need to pick her up and cuddle her."

(Image: Getty Images/iStockphoto)

Cannabis-based products have been available for medicinal use in Scotland, England and Wales since November.

The Scottish Government says specialist doctors are able to prescribe cannabis-based products after a decision is made it would be beneficial.

Last June, mum Lisa Quarrell told how she smuggled cannabis oil into Scotland to help her epileptic son.

Lisa, from East Kilbride, travelled to Holland to get the prescription for her six-year-old son Cole, who was fighting for his life.

When she returned she went to her son's hospital bed, where he lay, no longer able to move or speak, and placed a drop of cannabis oil under his tongue.

She said she did this several times a day and within two weeks Cole could walk again.

A week later, he could talk, she added.

Lisa said Cole went from having 16 seizures a night to none in more than 100 days.

The mum has since managed to get a private practice to issue a prescription.

Another mum, Karen Gray, told how she smuggled the drug into Scotland for her seven-year-old son Murray, who has Doose syndrome, a severe form of epilepsy.

She said it improved his condition and she has an importer who brings the drug to Scotland for £1,300 a month.

She added: “I’ve tried so many ­medications the NHS offers but nothing works.”
